Frandsen DEPARTMENT OF DAIRY HUSBANDRY NEBRASKA CONDITIONS FAVOR DAIRYING. Conditions in Nebraska are remarkably favorable for dairying and we may expect to see this one of the leading dairy states in the Union; but the industry here is as yet in its infancy and many years will elapse before it reaches its full "safe and sane" development. The operation of a creamery may be profitable to a community, but it is not a venture to be rushed into blindly without a thoro knowledge of the subject and local conditions. There are many districts in the state which are thinly settled and other sections where the people are more or less indifferent to dairying. In these districts the small cooperative creamery can scarcely hope to be successful. It is under these conditions that the centralized creamery with its cream station and cream routes fills a niche and opens up a market that could not, for a time at least, be had in any other way. FIRST THING IN STARTING A NEW CREAMERY. When a sufficient amount of interest in a cooperative creamery has manifested itself, the first thing to be done is to carefully ascertain how many dairy cows within a radius of seven or eight miles can be counted on regularly for the support of the creamery. In taking this cow census, special emphasis should be laid on the necessity of getting the actual number of cows that can be counted on to furnish cream for the new creamery. If fewer than about 600 available cows are found in this terri - tory, the project had better be indefinitely postponed. ORGANIZATION. If it be found that there is a sufficient number of cows to give reasonable assurance of success, then the organization should be given most careful consideration, and again I would advise that the farmers do their own organizing, and that not too many city people without cows be admitted. I would qualify this by saying that frequently on account of superior training it may be desirable to select a well-trained business man as financial manager. HOW TO RAISE THE MONEY. The most satisfactory way of raising the money is for each member to sign an agreement and to be jointly responsible for the amount bor - rowed. When such an agreement is signed by a goodly number of responsible farmers, the money can generally be secured at a reasonable rate of interest, and with this money a creamery can be erected and equipped. As soon as the creamery begins operation, arrangements can be made for a deduction of one or two cents per pound of butter to go into a "sinking fund" out of which the debt is paid. The payment is so gradual that the farmer hardly notices it. This plan has the advantage of requiring each patron to pay exactly in proportion to the amount of butter manufactured for him. COST OF CREAMERY PLANT. The cost of a creamery building will be from $1,000.00 to $2,500.00, depending on the locality, kind of construction, and cost of material and labor. Such a building usually consists of a main work room, engine

■boiler room (including space for refrigerating machine), coal room, gerator, storeroom and office. Machinery for a gathered cream plant will cost approximately $1,200.00. If refrigerating machinery is included, the cost will be from $800.00 to $1,000.00 more. The total cost of a creamery with complete equipment would therefore vary from $2,200.00 to $4,700.00 for a gath - ered cream creamery. This estimate, of course, does not provide for a large commission for a promoter, but, rather, is made on the assumption that the building is constructed by the responsible local contractor sub - mitting the lowest bid, and that the needed creamery machinery is ordered from a reliable creamery supply house willing to furnish the same for the lowest cash price. From facts and figures at hand it is estimated that the plan suggested would save the community from $1,200.00 to $2,000.00. The most serious objections to the "promoted" creamery is not the long list of wrecked creameries, nor the loss by the community of so much hard-earned cash, but it is the setback which the dairy interest suffers whenever one of these creameries fails, resulting in prejudice against the dairy business as a whole. To state it conservatively, it can be said, that for every one of these failures the dairy industry of that community has been set back at least ten years.
